item.title: Mobile Web Development with Drupal
item.description:
Speaker(s): 
MrMaksimize

Mobile web consumption is on the rise.

In 2010, global mobile data traffic tripled for the third year in a row. Between 2010 and 2015 Cisco predicts that there will be approximately 7.1 billion mobile devices connected to the web (roughly one per person on this planet)
Cisco

By 2014, mobile internet usage is expected to overtake desktop internet usage.
GigaOm: Mary Meeker of Morgan Stanley

Numerous people today already access the internet exclusively on their smartphones and do not own a desktop/laptop machine.

As Drupal developers, designers and themers, it's foolish for us to continue to assume that our work will only be viewed on a laptop or a desktop screen.

Today's website must deliver a tailored experience to the mobile web user that utilizes unique capabilities only available on such a device - geolocation, screen rotation, etc. This experience must be just as flawless as it is on their full size device. The mobile user expects personalization, interactivity and adjustments to his / her context.

**This session is intended for those responsible for creating such experiences: architects, developers, themers and designers.**

What questions will your session answer?: 
What does a user expect when using a mobile site / web application?
What are the different device classes and capabilities?
How do I detect if a mobile browser is visiting my site and what kind?
What are the technical challenges and how to work around them (or use them to my advantage)?
What are the mobile web development tools, modules and technologies at my disposal?
Track: 
Build
Experience level: 
Intermediate

item.title: Reality Bites: Business Pitfalls, Perils, and Truths to Moving/Rebuilding Really Big Websites
item.description:
Speaker(s): 
m3fan
Speaker(s): 
kherda

Managing expectations, dealing with the unexpected, helping shepherd change, managing internal and external resouces, and coping with insane timelines are all part of moving/re-launching large websites.

Follow us as we take a journey through the soft side of huge website launches and everything that goes with them: data migrations, wireframes, change management, expectation management, taxonomy cleanup, and more. We will be wading through strategy, not code.

In the past year we've completely re-built and relaunched: www.bdcnetwork.com, www.housingzone.com, www.constructionequipment.com, www.wwdmag.com, www.roadsbridges.com, www.itnonline.com, www.dicardiology.com and we've got a half dozen more to go. This is where we live and breathe on a daily basis.

What questions will your session answer?: 
How can I manage client/stakeholder expectations?
What are the top myths of large site migrations/launches?
How do I streamline designer to developer interaction?
What to expect just before launch and just after launch?

item.title: Bricks: Using ctools efficiently in Drupal 7
item.description:
Speaker(s): 
bangpound

Bricks is a new Drupal project that creates re-usable blocks out of ctools content types. It brings out some of the features more typically associated with Panels into Drupal core. The project itself is useful for site builders who want to create various kinds of ctools-exportable blocks without the overhead of Panels. Panels can be a big commitment especially for builders who aren't familiar with it.

Bricks leverages ctools to offer functionality that previously was primarily available through Panels, so it offers additional examples of how to use ctools features like contexts, content types, access control and export UI in your own work.

Learning ctools is imperative for Drupal coders. Because as a dependency of Views, it's very likely going to be on every Drupal 7 site you work on. If you don't know ctools, you're either writing code you don't need to or missing opportunities to integrate with other fantastic projects like Contextual Administration and Panels.

If you're working in Drupal 6, ctools brings Drupal 7 features to Drupal 6 and is also a helpful bridge that makes upgrading much easier.

This session is 25% builder and 75% coder. When I make a screencast demonstrating Bricks, I'll link it in this proposal and revise the description to focus on coding.

What questions will your session answer?: 
What can I use ctools for?
Why should I use ctools as much as possible?
How can I get some of the power of Panels but for a smaller and shorter project?
Track: 
Code
Experience level: 
Intermediate

item.title: Block Entites are Awesome

This allows your editors to create blocks with the ease of creating a node, without needing to write code or deal with a complex admin.

The session will demonstrate how to create block types, both in code and in UI. The session will also show different ways of using block entities, including the Blockreference module, which allows editors an easy-to-understand way to place blocks within a node, and demonstrate how Beans can be used to provide an alternative method of creating Views-driven blocks.

What is a block type?
How is the Bean module coded API First?
What is involved in making a block type plugin.
Can Bean replace Views Blocks?
What page layout options does Bean assist with?

item.title: Oh the things you can do… with an API!
item.description:
Speaker(s): 
MrMaksimize

Most successful companies on the web today from Amazon to Dropbox to Google to Twitter expose some kind of API to their users to write their own applications and interact with their application programmatically. They expose an even deeper API for their internal teams.

Even Dries recognizes the importance of being able to output data in different formats and now Drupal has an awesome
Web Services and Context Core Initiative

With Drupal, your site doesn't have to be big, or small, or even cool to have an API. It just has to be running Drupal! (So by definition it would be cool anyways).

In this session we'll delve into a discussion of APIs built using the Services Module. We'll talk about how internal APIs can be leveraged to transform your website into an SOA application and how external APIs can bring more adoption and flexibility to your online application. We'll talk about the definition of a true RESTful API and how to design your APIs to conform to those principles as well as the business logic of your website.

Also a hidden easter egg, we'll talk about how you can document it while typing minimal documentation.

Finally, at the end, we'll talk about the structure of the services module and how it works on the inside and at the end of the session we'll take a look at how to define your APIs in code!

What questions will your session answer?: 
Why do I even need / want an API?
How do I design an API to comply with my business logic and RESTful Principles?
How do I successfuly leverage APIs internally in my web application?
How do I make the people developing on my external API want to develop on my external API?
How do I actually code a services API?

Code

Intermediate

item.title: View Modes: The Many Faces of Your Content
item.description:
Speaker(s): 
tim.cosgrove

View Modes are a core feature of Drupal 7 entities that most users don’t give too much thought to, even though they use them all the time. This is a shame because View Modes are an extraordinarily powerful tool for streamlining the theming and development of your site and ensuring consistency of output for your content. View Modes give the themer the ability to show the same content in many different contexts and with the right display for each situation. Through smart use of View Modes, a themer can avoid having the huge stack of node templates and Views displays that we’re used to.

In this session, attendees will learn what a View Mode is and how to create custom View Modes both in code and with contributed modules. We’ll demonstrate how to set and export display settings for all of your View Modes. We will also spend time looking at the design strategies and types of site elements that View Modes are well suited for. We’ll will see how View Modes can change the way you template your nodes, lay out your content, and interact with developers, all for the better.

What questions will your session answer?: 
What is a View Mode, and how do I make my own?
How do I export my View Modes to code?
How can View Modes improve my theming practices and collaboration with developers?
What design strategies are View Modes particularly well-suited for?
What other core features and contrib modules do View Modes work well with?
Track: 
Design
Experience level: 
Advanced

item.title: Content access control in Drupal
item.description:
Speaker(s): 
xjm

Drupal's node access system is powerful and flexible under the hood, but most site builders need node access control modules to harness it. Unfortunately, node access modules tend not to play well with others! This session will introduce the fundamentals of access control for experienced site builders and aspiring module developers. I'll discuss four types of access control in Drupal:

  1. The permission system
  2. The node access system
  3. The menu system
  4. Query alters

I will also share some tips and troubleshooting advice. The session will cover access control in both Drupal 6 and Drupal 7, and I'll also mention what might be on the horizon for Drupal 8.

What questions will your session answer?: 
What access control is built into Drupal core?
What contributed modules can I use to control access?
How does node access work "under the hood"?
How do I troubleshoot access control modules?
What is changing in Drupal 7 and Drupal 8?

item.title: Taxi Cab Confessions - creating mobile enterprise apps with Drupal
item.description:
Today’s mobile devices have taken over as the most cost-effective and scalable way to replace legacy hardware solutions, as well as paper solutions, that were both clunky and expensive for users. One taxicab company – Green Cab of Madison – has adopted Apple iPads as their vehicle meter and communication device in their Toyota Prius green cabs. Their iPads are outfitted with a mobile app built on Drupal that enables them to collect real-time vehicle location data, to alert drivers of new calls, and to complete credit card transactions.

Promet will share the story of how they built the iPad app for Green Cab Madison to help them take advantage of mobile technology and optimize their business.

What questions will your session answer?: 
How Drupal was leveraged for rapid development of the base dispatch application
Why Drupal was the right choice for integrating with native and hybrid mobile apps
Where Drupal can be used for enterprise mobile application development

item.title: BEANs (Block Entities) for Themers, Site Developers, and Editors
item.description:
Speaker(s): 
tim.cosgrove

BEANs, or Block Entities, are a powerful new tool for giving your users the ability to create their own blocks quickly and easily. BEANs do this with tools that users understand and can use without site builder or developer intervention. This can be combined with other modules to allow users to create pages that are modular, dynamic, and completely under their control.

In this session we will go over what the BEAN module is, how site builders can create new BEAN types in the admin, and how to theme them. We will also discuss modules that work well together with BEAN, and look at strategies for building pages with beans. The audience for this session includes themers, site builders, and producers.

What questions will your session answer?: 
What are BEANs, or block entities?
How are BEANs useful to me?

What design and site building strategies do BEANs enable?
